title: 114_hr6510
content: The Act may be cited as the "Save the Children Act of 2016". The Congress acknowledges the importance of saving children. The "Save the Children Act of 2016" acknowledges the humanitarian crisis faced by Syrian children due to the civil war violence. It calls for the temporary relocation and care of up to 25,000 young Syrian minor children refugees in the United States over three years. The Act calls for the temporary relocation and care of up to 25,000 young Syrian child refugees in the United States over three years. Efforts should be made to facilitate family reunification or safe relocation of these children back to Syria after a substantial reduction in civil war violence and displaced inhabitants. The Save the Children Program is established under Section 3 of the Act to provide temporary relocation and care for up to 25,000 young Syrian child refugees in the United States with the goal of facilitating family reunification or safe relocation back to Syria after a decrease in civil war violence. The Save the Children Program grants visas for young Syrian children aged three to ten to enter the US until civil war violence decreases. A six-month grace period is given before visas expire to reunify children with their families. Only children with established guardians present or orphaned are eligible for visas. An Office of Coordination is established in the Office of Refugee. The Save the Children Program allows young Syrian children aged three to ten to enter the US until civil war violence decreases. An Office of Coordination is established in the Office of Refugee Resettlement to oversee the program's operations in the United States. The Coordinator appointed by the Secretary of Health and Human Services can hire additional personnel as needed. The Coordinator appointed by the Secretary of Health and Human Services can request personnel from federal departments to assist in carrying out duties under the Save the Children Program. The Coordinator will also utilize resources from the Division of Unaccompanied Children's Services. The Coordinator is responsible for identifying young minor children who qualify for the program. The Coordinator appointed by the Secretary of Health and Human Services is responsible for implementing the Save the Children Program by obtaining custody of children, resettling them in the United States, cooperating with organizations and government authorities, and consulting with relevant officials to ensure program operations. Homeland Security oversees Program operations to ensure compliance with laws and international agreements, with the goal of family reunification within six months of reduced violence in Syria. The Program will terminate six months after certification of reduced violence and displacement in Syria. The Program overseen by Homeland Security aims to reunite minor children admitted to the United States with their parents or caretakers within six months of reduced violence in Syria. The Program may be suspended or terminated if deemed necessary for US foreign policy and domestic security interests. The Coordinator overseeing the Program under Homeland Security must report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment on the implementation details. Appropriations are authorized for each fiscal year to support the Program's objectives, with funds potentially sourced from the Migration and Refugee Assistance Act of 1962. SEC. 4. TEMPORARY NONIMMIGRANT VISA. The Program under section (b) allows for the admission of alien minor children aged three to ten years old, with a preference for those already in custody outside Syria. A temporary nonimmigrant visa is granted until the Secretary of State certifies a reduction in civil war violence and displaced Syria inhabitants. The Syrian Civil War Minor Child Protection Act of 2016 allows for the temporary admission of alien children aged three to ten from Syria or displaced elsewhere, under the Save the Children Program. This is facilitated by the Department of State in consultation with other relevant authorities. Aliens admitted to the United States under the Save the Children Act of 2016 can stay until the Secretary of State certifies a significant reduction in civil war violence in Syria and newly displaced Syrian inhabitants. A six-month grace period is provided for reunification efforts.
